title: Court rejects `first in, first served' claim for AMP class action
text:
The judge said it "depends on a prima facie conclusion that subsequent proceedings are vexatious and oppressive" and would "cast an onus that would be very difficult to discharge".

He also backed comments by Federal Court Chief Justice James Allsop that "all courts should be astute to protect the best interests of all group members, not the desires of the promoters and managers of the litigation (in particular, the commercial funders and the lawyers)".

President Bell suggested there was little disadvantage in Quinn Emanuel's lead plaintiff joining the other claim and agreed with AMP that more than one claim would be "vexatious and oppressive".

He also rejected an argument "that it was in some way 'unjudicial' for the court to be making an assessment of ... the best interests of group members in terms of the likely financial outcome of proceedings for members of the group, even on a provisional basis".

'Just, quick and cheap'

President Bell said it sat squarely within the obligation to find a "just, quick and cheap resolution" for a dispute.

However, he took issue with comments by the full Federal Court in the Get Swift case that judges could look at which law firm was "most experienced and capable" when deciding who should proceed with a claim. (Justice Ward said she found argument on this front "unedifying".)

"Not only may the most experienced not be the most capable, but the criteria for the assessment of capability may be highly subjective and the evaluation of capability quite problematic,'' he said.

"The whole process would not only be invidious for the court but also, in my opinion, it would take the court to territory into which it is inappropriate for it to travel."
description: An AMP class action appeal finds there is no first-mover advantage.
